repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
- add clang-tidy configuration file
- enable additional useful checks through `clangd` that are nice to have (naming-conventions, etc)

references:
   - https://github.com/googleapis/google-cloud-cpp/blob/main/.clang-tidy
   - https://wiki.sei.cmu.edu/confluence/display/c/Clang

---

Related: #10632, #11236, #15428

comment_data.body:
Only if you want a way to run it per-file from the CLI. If you're running `clangd` then it can also manage `clang-tidy` for you and dynamically display any warnings and code-actions through LSP.

Alternatively, we can introduce another target called  `clang-tidy-file` or something, which would allow us to skip validating the variable inside make.

I didn't want to do conditional run from inside make, because that would get hacky very quickly: https://stackoverflow.com/a/45003119

comment_data.body:
My bad, I didn't notice it. 

It's just the standard way to let the other tools find it without hard-coding the build path. I wanted to use $(BUILD_DIR) but it's not defined.

```make
ln -sf $(BUILD_DIR)/compile_commands.json .
```

There are a few ways for cmake to use it:
1) your typical 
```shell
cd $BUILD_DIR && cmake .. 
```
2) by setting the `CMAKE_BINARY_DIR=..` variable
2) my favorite, but I believe it's relatively new so I need to check which is the oldest supported cmake version
```shell
cmake -B $BUILD_DIR
```

comment_data.body:
I think this could be done without much hassle inside the makefile. Something like the following should work:

```
FILE ?= $(shell git ls-files *.c)
clang-tidy: generate-compilation-db
	  clang-tidy --config-file .clang-tidy -p build $(FILE)
```

So if it's run as `make clang-tidy` then all files will be used. If it's run with `make clang-tidy FILE=src/nvim/screen.c` then it's only used on `screen.c`.

comment_data.body: afaik we decided against this kind of change in the uncrustify discussions.

what about multiple initializations on one line?

```c
int pc = 0, pc1 = 1, nc = 3;
```

IMO these are extremely error prone and ought to be split up. If it's the same rule that governs both then I think we should not do this (but if it's possible to behave differently for initialized and uninitialized declarations then I have no objection).
i'm ok either way. @neovim/core +1 / -1
this is not worth adding as a build target, it is just `clint.py` with some arbitrary options.
doesn't clang-tidy find this implicitly? that was the reason for putting it in the root dir instead of a subdir like config/
